breaking_news.title: Apple Patches Decade-Old iOS Zero-Day Exploited in Sophisticated Targeted Attacks
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Apple released emergency security updates across iOS, macOS, watchOS, tvOS, and visionOS to patch CVE-2026-20700, a memory corruption vulnerability in the Dynamic Link Editor (dyld) affecting every iOS version since 1.0. The flaw enables arbitrary code execution and was actively exploited in a highly sophisticated attack chain involving CVE-2025-14174 and CVE-2025-43529 against pre-iOS 26 devices. Google’s Threat Analysis Group discovered and reported the issue, indicating likely nation-state or commercial spyware involvement.

Paragraph 2: The vulnerability was used to compromise specific high-value targets, potentially enabling full device control, credential theft, and persistent surveillance. This marks Apple’s first actively exploited zero-day of 2026 and underscores the increasing use of legacy, unpatched flaws in targeted campaigns. Organizations and individuals with sensitive data on Apple devices must prioritize immediate patching to mitigate risk.

breaking_news.title: Malicious Outlook Add-In Hijacked to Steal 4,000+ Microsoft Credentials via Abandoned Domain
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A previously legitimate Outlook add-in named AgreeTo—originally an open-source meeting scheduler—was hijacked after its developer abandoned the project and its Vercel-hosted backend URL expired. A threat actor reclaimed the outlook-one.vercel.app subdomain and repurposed it to serve a phishing kit that stole over 4,000 Microsoft account credentials, credit card numbers, and security answer responses. The attack exploited Microsoft’s one-time manifest signing model, which does not monitor runtime changes to add-in URLs.

Paragraph 2: This represents a novel supply chain attack vector where trusted Microsoft Office infrastructure is weaponized via domain reuse. The compromise impacts enterprise users across finance, healthcare, government, and education sectors, highlighting critical gaps in continuous monitoring of third-party add-ins. Microsoft and security researchers are urging organizations to audit installed add-ins and enforce stricter domain governance.

breaking_news.title: APT31 Used Google Gemini AI to Plan Cyberattacks Against US Critical Infrastructure
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Google’s Threat Analysis Group (GTIG) revealed that China-linked APT31 leveraged Google’s Gemini AI chatbot to automate vulnerability analysis and plan cyber operations against US organizations. The group conducted “distillation attacks” to extract Gemini’s reasoning capabilities and used it to identify weaknesses in critical infrastructure systems. This marks the first confirmed case of a state-sponsored actor integrating generative AI into the planning phase of cyber operations.

Paragraph 2: The use of AI significantly accelerates reconnaissance and exploit development timelines, lowering the barrier for sophisticated attacks. This development signals a new era where APTs weaponize publicly accessible AI tools to enhance tradecraft, raising concerns about broader adoption by other nation-state actors. Organizations must now consider AI-assisted threat modeling in their defense strategies and prioritize patching of exposed systems.

breaking_news.title: LummaStealer Resurfaces with Surge in Infections Post-Law Enforcement Takedown
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Bitdefender reported a sharp resurgence in LummaStealer activity following the May 2025 law enforcement takedown that seized 2,300 C2 domains and dark web markets. The Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) infostealer has rebounded through renewed affiliate campaigns using fake cracked software, ClickFix CAPTCHA lures, and integration with CastleLoader malware. Microsoft’s Digital Crimes Unit sinkholed over 1,300 domains to intercept traffic and support remediation efforts.

Paragraph 2: LummaStealer’s recovery demonstrates the resilience of MaaS operations and the difficulty of dismantling decentralized criminal ecosystems. Its resurgence threatens financial institutions, healthcare providers, and enterprises globally, with stolen credentials feeding broader credential-stuffing and ransomware campaigns. Organizations must strengthen endpoint detection, user awareness, and domain reputation monitoring to counter this evolving threat.

breaking_news.title: ZeroDayRAT Spyware Kit Enables Full iOS and Android Compromise via Telegram
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A newly discovered commercial mobile spyware platform, ZeroDayRAT, is being sold on Telegram for approximately $1,000 and offers full remote access to both Android and iOS devices—including live camera feeds, keylogging, banking data theft, and location tracking. Developed by an unconfirmed threat actor, the toolkit rivals nation-state-grade capabilities and requires no technical expertise to deploy. Infections occur via smishing, phishing, fake apps, or malicious links shared on messaging platforms.

Paragraph 2: ZeroDayRAT’s availability to low-sophistication actors democratizes high-end surveillance capabilities, significantly increasing the risk to individuals, journalists, activists, and corporate employees. Its integration with custom control panels and server hosting options enables scalable, persistent espionage. Mobile users and enterprises must prioritize device hardening, app source verification, and MFA enforcement to mitigate exposure.

breaking_news.title: UNC3886 Targets Singapore’s Entire Telecom Sector with Zero-Day and Rootkits
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: China-linked APT UNC3886 conducted a sustained cyber espionage campaign against all four major Singapore telecom providers—Singtel, StarHub, M1, and Simba Telecom—using zero-day exploits, rootkits, and custom backdoors. Operation CYBER GUARDIAN, involving over 100 personnel, was launched to contain the breach. The group prioritized stealth over disruption, avoiding customer data exposure but embedding persistent access in network infrastructure.

Paragraph 2: This operation highlights the strategic targeting of critical telecom infrastructure by state-sponsored actors to enable long-term intelligence gathering and potential future disruption. The use of zero-days and rootkits underscores the sophistication of modern APTs and the vulnerability of telco supply chains. Governments and telcos must adopt zero-trust architectures and enhance threat hunting for passive, long-dwell intrusions.

breaking_news.title: Microsoft February Patch Tuesday Fixes Six Actively Exploited Zero-Days Including Shell Bypass
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft’s February 2026 Patch Tuesday addressed 59 vulnerabilities, including six actively exploited zero-days—five of which were publicly known. Critical flaws include CVE-2026-21510 (Windows Shell SmartScreen bypass), CVE-2026-21513 (MSHTML bypass), and CVE-2026-21533 (RDP privilege escalation). These flaws enable attackers to suppress security prompts, execute arbitrary code, and escalate privileges with minimal user interaction.

Paragraph 2: CISA added six of these flaws to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating federal agency remediation within 30 days. The high number of exploited zero-days reflects ongoing pressure on enterprise defenses and the rapid weaponization of patched flaws by threat actors. Organizations must prioritize patching, especially for internet-facing systems, and deploy exploit mitigation tools like ASLR and CFG.

breaking_news.title: Conduent Data Breach Expands to 25 Million Impacted After Volvo Group, Texas, and Oregon Confirmed
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Business services provider Conduent confirmed a massive data breach affecting at least 25 million individuals—far exceeding initial estimates of 10 million. The breach, stemming from a January 2025 cyberattack, exposed sensitive PII including Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, health records, and insurance information. Volvo Group North America confirmed nearly 17,000 employees were impacted, while Texas and Oregon revealed 15 million and over 10 million affected residents respectively.

Paragraph 2: As a major HR and benefits outsourcing vendor, Conduent’s compromise has cascading effects across critical sectors including automotive, state governments, and healthcare. The breach underscores systemic risks in third-party vendor ecosystems and highlights the need for enhanced supply chain security assessments. Affected individuals should monitor credit reports and consider identity theft protection services.
